Authors:
Yi Chung Lin, Che-Chih Chen, Sheng-Hua WU, Chia-Ling Wei,
Chi-Yu chen
Title:
Three new species of Cylindrobasidium (Physalacriaceae,
Agaricales) from East Asia
Keywords:
corticioid fungi  phylogeny  taxonomy  wood-inhabiting
fungi.
Abstract:
Species of corticioid genus Cylindrobasidium are
saprophytes or parasites in forest ecosystems. This study presents three
new species of Cylindrobasidium from East Asia, according to
morphological characteristics and phylogenetic analyses based on
sequence data inferred from nuc rDNA internal transcribed spacer
ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 (ITS) region and nuc 28S rDNA (28S). Cylindrobasidium
bifidus grows on dead or living branches of angiosperm (e.g.,
Broussonetia papyrifera) in SW China, Taiwan and northern Vietnam, and
is characterized by having effused, cream basidiocarps with smooth
hymenophore, presence of subicular cystidia with bifurcate apex,
presence of fusiform hymenial cystidia, and pyriform basidiospores.
Cylindrobasidium macrosporum grows on angiosperm branches in subtropical
Taiwan, is characterized by having effused, ivory-colored basidiocarps
with smooth to tuberculate hymenophore, presence of guttulate, subicular
cystidia with bifurcate apex, presence of guttulate, cylindrical
hymenial cystidia with narrow apices, and large, guttulate, fusiform
basidiospores. Cylindrobasidium sublaeve grows on angiosperm branches in
SW China and Taiwan, and is characterized by having effused-reflexed,
cream or pinkish-buff basidiocarps with smooth hymenophore, presence of
subfusiform or cylindrical hymenial cystidia, and pyriform
basidiospores.
